awd_titl_txt: Derived Categories, Hodge Theory, and Birational Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
Algebraic geometry is the study of the geometric objects -- called algebraic varieties -- defined by systems of polynomial equations. A fundamental problem is to classify algebraic varieties, i.e. to determine when one can be transformed into another using algebraic functions. The main theme of this project is to study the classification problem using certain algebraic invariants (derived categories and Hodge structures), which can be thought of as sophisticated "linear approximations" to algebraic varieties. These invariants have connections to many fields, ranging from number theory to symplectic geometry and high energy physics. 

The project has three related parts. The first is to use Bridgeland stability conditions to prove results about the geometry and period mappings of Fano varieties; this relies on a newly developed notion of stability conditions in families, and the existence of noncommutative K3 surfaces in the derived categories of certain Fano varieties. The second part is to construct more examples of noncommutative K3 surfaces, and to further develop the theory of homological projective geometry (which gives a powerful tool for studying noncommutative varieties in general). The third part is to study geometric problems suggested by the first two parts, concerning the rationality of algebraic varieties and the construction of holomorphic symplectic varieties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported research in algebraic geometry, a subject which concerns the solution spaces to systems of polynomial equations, known as algebraic varieties. The primary theme was the study of these spaces by means of the derived category, which can be regarded as a sophisticated type of linearization. In contrast to an algebraic variety which is made up of a space of points, the derived category has a more algebraic nature, consisting of a collection of objects (complexes of coherent sheaves) and relations (derived morphisms) between them. This perspective has powered recent advances in algebraic geometry as well as related fields like representation theory, symplectic geometry, and mathematical physics.  

While supported by this grant, the PI (together with coauthors) introduced and applied new tools for analyzing derived categories, leading to the following outcomes:

1. Structural results for derived categories, including theorems that break them into smaller pieces with nice categorical properties.

2. An extension of the theory of stability conditions on derived categories to the relative setting, where the variety may vary, as well as descriptions of moduli spaces of stable objects in interesting examples.

3. A version of Hodge theory for derived categories and their semiorthogonal components, with applications to the integral Hodge conjecture for varieties.

The PI also engaged in broader impacts activities, including advising PhD students, mentoring postdocs, organizing and speaking at seminars and conferences, and delivering lecture series aimed at early career mathematicians.
